title: People unnecessarily seek ways to 'detox' from COVID-19 vaccine
author: David Wenner; Dwenner Com
description: Searches for regimens have increased as more vaccine-reluctant people get vaccinated.
cleaned_text: Recent months have brought increased online searches by people seeking information on how to flush COVID-19 vaccine out of their bodies. Anti-vaxx social media influencers are creating and feeding demand, offering methods and recipes which have included borax, normally used as a cleaner and pesticide. Medical News Today wrote: "Suggestions for 'detoxes' after receiving a COVID-19 vaccine ranged from borax baths to detox diets. Suggested detox diets included high fat diets to 'bind the toxins' in the vaccines, alongside supplements, including zinc and vitamins C and D." [Borax can be harmful if swallowed and can irritate the skin, according to WebMD. ](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/borax-sodium-tetraborate) Some of the more extreme claims advise taking doses of ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine to offset the impact of COVID-19 vaccine, according to Medical News Today. Neither of those have been proven effective against COVID-19. [Medical News Today is considered a credible, pro-science news source,](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/can-you-detox-from-the-covid-19-vaccine?utm_source=Sailthru%20Email&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=newsAlerts&utm_term=coronavirus&utm_content=2021-12-07&apid=39029251&rvid=42eafc65c9d134b442d4f7adaddca0375c44f6ec6db3d2c122a156d2ddcc6772) relying on well-credentialed sources and linking to studies it mentions in articles. It publishes a daily newsletter devoted to new research and news related to COVID-19. [Information about its editorial standards can be found here. ](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/about) Much of the demand for vaccine detox seems to be coming from people who reluctantly got vaccinated because of a mandate. It's further fueled by misinformation claiming COVID-19 vaccines contain metals, or they deliberately change the body in ways unrelated to preventing COVID-19, or even contain "nanotechnologies" capable of altering or controlling human behavior. Assorted news organizations have looked into and debunked the claims, which are often based on misinformation related to the mRNA technology used in the two most prominent COVID-19 vaccines in the United States. The fact-checking [site Politifact explained that mRNA technology has been around since the 1990s. ](https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2021/oct/21/carrie-madej/transhumanism-nanotechnology-covid-19-vaccine-cons/)Although this is the first time it has been widely used in vaccines, it has long been considered safe and also holds promise for treating diseases including cancer. Politifact wrote: "RNA — ribonucleic acid — is a molecule similar to DNA that carries coded genetic information to a cell. The Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines use a form called messenger RNA, or mRNA, to carry genetic information about the coronavirus to the body's cells to teach the immune system to identify and prepare to fight off a COVID-19 infection. It does not modify a person's DNA or RNA." NBC News noted that supposed detox remedies have long been part of the anti-vaccine movement. "Long before Covid, anti-vaccine influencers and alternative health entrepreneurs promoted unproven and sometimes dangerous treatments they claimed would rid children of the alleged toxins that lingered after routine childhood immunizations," [NBC News wrote.](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/covid-vaccine-mandates-push-holdouts-get-shot-detox-rcna4859) Monica Gandhi, a professor of medicine at the University of California San Francisco, told Medical News Today that if COVID-19 vaccines were harmful, the evidence would be obvious by now. She said: "7.4 billion doses have been administered now worldwide, of different vaccines with COVID, and a lot of those are mRNA vaccines. So you know, if there were a lot of adverse events, we would have seen a lot of damage. But we don't see that." The number of doses has increased since her remarks.
